name: Hamerkop
description: The hamerkop could go unnoticed due to its brown coloration and medium size, if not for the striking crest on its head, which earned it its Czech name.
spread_note: Africa south of the Sahara, Madagascar, southwestern Arabia
image_alt: Hamerkop, photo: Petr Rošický, Prague Zoo
proportions: Body length 32–40 cm; tail length 15–16 cm; wing length 30–31.5 cm; weight 415–430 g
attractions: This wading bird shows its relation to herons—it hunts similarly: standing motionless to ambush prey, then striking swiftly with its sharp beak. They build enormous, roofed nests up to 1.5 m in diameter, with an entrance below and a tunnel over half a meter long. They typically construct several, and unused nests are taken over by genets, owls, and other animals.
breeding: Hamerkops were kept in the 1970s and 1980s, with a chick successfully raised in 1976. Breeding paused from 1993 to 2010, resuming with new individuals tied to the opening of the Bird Wetlands exhibit. They began nesting in 2012.
